As in anything, there are various ways to do things. Also, inidividuals wil=
l have different approaches to the same problems.

I think we can all agree=
 that the tool should just provide the knobs and let the user decide which =
way to turn them.

[Robert Lucente]  -----Original Message-----
From: junit=
@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com]On Behalf Of Elliotte Harold=

Sent: Saturday, January 21, 2006 11:09 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subjec=
t: Re: [junit] Unit 4.0 release candidate 2 Test ordering


  C=C3=A9dric B=
eust =E2=99=94 wrote:

  > You just said it yourself:  when you see 1001 te=
sts failed, you know it's
  > actually only 1 test that failed  and it took=
 down the other 1000.

  No, that's not it at all. 1 test did not fail and =
take down the other 
  1000. Something else outside the test suite failed a=
nd took down all 
  1001 tests. My tests don't depend on each other but the=
y do have shared 
  dependencies on things like whether the cat pulled the =
Ethernet cable 
  out of the back of my computer or the web server crashed =
or I moved a 
  third party jar file.

  > Wouldn't it be nice if the frame=
work told you exactly *which* test failed
  > instead of you having to pin =
down which test starts the Web server or which
  > tests opens a JDBC conne=
ction among thousands?

  There's rarely one test that points right to this=
 sort of problems. 
  There are many tests each one of which independently =
fails as a result 
  of these problems. The failure of many different tests=
 is a clear sign 
  that I should look for broad environmental problems rat=
her than specific 
  bugs in code.


  -- 
  =EF=BB=BFElliotte Rusty Harold=
